releaseNotes.title: Big update
releaseNotes.description: This is the first big update for Chart Your Music containing updates to the overall UI, support for import and export of collections, import of Apple Music editorial notes, sharing your charts with MusicThread, improved in-ap on-boarding and support, new  MusicKit for Apple Music integration, and support for large number of new iOS 15 features.

supportPages.title: What
supportPages.subtitle: With Chart Your Music you will be able to create collections of charts (e.g. Top 40 2020, Best Albums 2000) of the music you love and then create charts ranking your songs, albums, tracks, either daily, weekly, monthly, unordered. Over time, Chart Your Music will become your musical diary.

supportPages.title: Who
supportPages.subtitle: This app is for music lovers that need more than the yearly 'what did I listen to' lists of Apple Music and Spotify. Be in control of your own charts, not solely determined by (accidental) listening behaviour but carefully curated by you.

supportPages.title: Organize
supportPages.subtitle: Organize your charts in collections. E.g. *My Albums 2021*.

supportPages.title: Sequence
supportPages.subtitle: Create charts in a collection, daily, weekly, unordered… Whatever you prefer.

supportPages.title: Rank
supportPages.subtitle: Rank music entries in a chart in line with you musical taste.

headerItems.title: What's New in Chart Your Music

supportPages.title: Details, details, details!
supportPages.subtitle: Explore all kind of details (like cover art, liner notes, producers, ratings, etc.) about your entries using your music service and sources like Last.fm, Discogs, Genius

supportPages.title: Any Playlist as a Chart
supportPages.subtitle: Import a chart playlist (Apple Music) or any playlist (as a new chart) into a collection…

supportPages.title: Works with Last.fm and NowPlaying
supportPages.subtitle: Integration with Last.fm for loved tracks and scrobbles. And with NowPlaying for a beautiful listening experience…

supportPages.title: Collections
supportPages.subtitle: The unique music collection you want to chart over time. E.g. *Best Tracks of 2021*, or *Old Disco Hits 1983*.

supportPages.title: Charts
supportPages.subtitle: The charts that make up the collection, e.g.*Week 1*, *January 3*, *August*.  You can have as many charts as part of a collection as you want. You determine the interval of charts within a collection: daily, weekly, monthly, irregularly or none at all…

supportPages.title: Chart
supportPages.subtitle: In each chart you rank your favorite entries according to your musical preference at that moment…

supportPages.title: Entries
supportPages.subtitle: The tracks / songs / albums that are part of your collection and can be ranked in a chart. E.g. *The Weekend - Blinding Lights*, or *Radiohead - OK Computer*.

supportPages.title: Chart Entries
supportPages.subtitle: The unique combination of an entry in a chart, specifying the position of an entry in the chart

supportPages.title: Select Your Music Service
supportPages.subtitle: Before you start creating your own collections, charts, entries, etc. ensure you have selected the integration with a music service you are subscribed to (e.g. Apple Music or Spotify) if any. If not, select iTunes.

supportPages.title: Create Your First Collection
supportPages.subtitle: Tap on **Charts** in the tab bar. In **Collections**, tap **+** in the navigation bar. Specify your collection details in the **Add Collection** sheet. Tap **Save**.

supportPages.title: Create Your First Chart
supportPages.subtitle: Tap on your collection (identified by its title). In your collection, tap **+** in the navigation bar. Specify your chart details in the **Add Chart** sheet and tap **Save**.

supportPages.title: Create Your First Entries
supportPages.subtitle: Tap on your chart. In your chart, tap on **+** and select **Search Entry…**. Enter search criteria and press **search**. From the list of results, tap on the specific entry you want to add to your chart. In the details screen, tap **+ Add Entry** to add the entry to your chart. Repeat to add more entries. Tap **Cancel**, **Done** when finished.

supportPages.title: Moving or Deleting Entries
supportPages.subtitle: Tap on **↔︎** or simply drag and drop. Your chart view changes so you can delete and move entries. Drag entries up or down using the handle of an entry. Tap on **-** to remove an entry from the chart (alternatively you can swipe from right to left, even when not in ranking view). Tap **⇅** when finished ranking your chart.

supportPages.title: Locking A Chart
supportPages.subtitle: When finished with your chart, swipe to right to lock it so all entries become part of calculating total points, number of entries, etc.. You can only lock a chart when entries in the chart are equal to the number of entries you defined for charts in your collection.

supportPages.title: Create Your Second Chart
supportPages.subtitle: Repeat earlier steps to create a new chart in the collection. Toggle **Duplicate Entries** on to automatically copy over all the entries from the previous chart.

supportPages.title: Pick Existing Entries
supportPages.subtitle: You can pick any entry in a collection not part of the current chart. Select **Pick Entry** and select entry from list or search for entry. Pick the one you want to add. You can sort the entries on artist/title (ascending) or on date (descending). Drag down to search.

supportPages.title: Import Examples
supportPages.subtitle: You can can import example collection. The examples differ based on the music service. Select **Settings** > **Manage Collections**, select **…** and then **Import Examples**. From the list select the example collections and tap **Import**

supportPages.title: Discover
supportPages.subtitle: You can can discover the music you hear by using the **Discover** tab. Tap **Discover…** and wait for the music to be discovered. Then tap **Add Entry…** to add music to a collection.

supportPages.title: View or Edit A Collection
supportPages.subtitle: Tap on **Charts** in tab bar. Tap on the collection you want to view or modify. Tap on the header (with the date of the collection). You will see the **Entries Overview** screen where you can rank and search for all entries in the collection. Tap on **…** and then **Edit** to modify collection details.

supportPages.title: View or Edit A Chart
supportPages.subtitle: Tap on **Charts** in the tab bar. Tap your collection. Tap your chart. Tap on header (with the date of the chart). You will see the **Chart Details** screen with an overview of movers in the chart. Tap on **Edit (pencil)** to modify chart details

supportPages.title: View or Edit An Entry
supportPages.subtitle: Tap on an entry in a chart or in the entries overview. You will see the **Entry Details** screen with an overview of total points, etc. Tap on **Edit (pencil)** to modify entry details.

supportPages.title: Positions In A Chart
supportPages.subtitle: In the **Edit Collection** sheet, unfold **Look & Feel**. Modify the colour for a position: Tap on the **colour** at the right, select your preferred colour using the colour picker and tap **x** to leave the picker. Repeat this for other positions. Tap **Save** to save your changes.

supportPages.title: Fast Movers
supportPages.subtitle: You can specify Fast Movers by defining the percentage of change. Tap **Save** to save changes.

supportPages.title: Artist or Title
supportPages.subtitle: Depending on what you think is more relevant for your collection, you can define whether your entries are displayed as **Artist** followed by **Title**, or **Title** followed by **Artist**. Tap **Save** to save changes.

supportPages.title: Number of Entries in a Chart
supportPages.subtitle: For a collection you define the number of entries for each chart in that collection. This number is used to validate whether a chart can be locked and to calculate (total) points. To define the number of entries, follow steps to edit a collection. In the **Edit Collection** sheet, specify the number of entries (default 10, minimum 1, maximum 50). Tap **Save** to save changes.

supportPages.title: Entry Details
supportPages.subtitle: You can view details of an entry by navigating to an entry from either within a chart or from the **Entry Overview** of a collection. The **Entry Details** screen show numbers for chart entries (in how many charts the entry is listed in), Nr. 1 Positions (how often the entry has reached the number 1 position), Highest Position (what has been the highest position for the entry across charts) and Total Points (the total points the entry has collected across charts).

supportPages.title: Chart Details
supportPages.subtitle: Follow steps to view or edit a chart. In **Chart Details**, tap on **Up** to see a list of entries that moved up in the chart, **Equal** to see a list of entries that did not move in the chart, **Down** to see a list of entries that moved down in the chart, **Intro** to see a list of entries that are new in the chart, **Outro** to see a list of entries that disappeared from the chart. Through a tap you can also toggle lock/unlock status of the chart.

supportPages.title: Collection Details
supportPages.subtitle: Tap on the collection you want to view or modify. Tap on the header (with the date of the collection). You will see the **Entries Overview** screen where you can rank and search for all entries in the collection.

supportPages.title: More Details
supportPages.subtitle: Tap on the image of an entry in the entry details. You will see the details of the entry from the selected music service. Explore more details even from other sources.

supportPages.title: Share Your Chart
supportPages.subtitle: You can share your chart using the iOS sharing functionality. Tap on **Charts** in tab bar. Tap on your collection. Tap on the specific chart. Tap on **Share**. What gets shared depends on the app you select.

supportPages.title: Create A Playlist
supportPages.subtitle: When Apple Music or Spotify is configured as a music service, you can create a playlist from a chart. Tap on **Charts** in tab bar. Tap on your collection. Tap on the specific chart. Tap on the header (with the date  of the chart). In **Chart Details** screen, tap on **…**, then on **Create Playlist…**. A playlist titled *CYM: collection name - chart name* will be created.

supportPages.title: Create A Thread
supportPages.subtitle: When you have authenticated with MusicThread, you can share your chart as a thread. Go to your chart and tap the header. In the **Chart Detail** screen, tap the **…** and then on **Create Thread…**. Fill in the details in the **MusicThread** sheet and submit your thread.

supportPages.title: Import Playlists
supportPages.subtitle: In your collection tap **Import**. A sheet will display your playlists from the configured music service. Select **Collection** to add to your collection, select **New Chart** to create a new chart from the playlist.

supportPages.title: Import / Export Collections
supportPages.subtitle: From **Settings** > **Manage Collections** you can import example collections, collections from your local device or available connected storages, or from a URL. When you select one or more collections, you can export these to a file. Collections are saved in JSON format.

items.title: What is the difference between the Home and Charts tab?
items.text: The **Home** tab shows totals for collections, charts, entries and chart entries. It also shows, for each collection, details like date and current number 1 entry of the most recent chart. Tap on a collection row to easily navigate to the most recent chart in that collection. The **Charts** tab gives you full access to all collections from where you can navigate to all charts within the collection and discover more details on the chart itself as well as on the individual entries in the chart.

items.title: What types of collections does the app support?
items.text: A collection can be a **sequence** of charts or just a **unordered** collection of charts. With a sequence, charts are ordered based on their chart date, and that date is used to calculate the previous position(s) of an entry. With no sequence configured for the collection, there is no order and/or relation between the charts in a collection. You could use this option if, for example, you want to collect charts from various sources (think end-of-year lists) as part of a collection. See the OOR21 collection for an example.

items.title: Can the app remind me of creating new charts?
items.text: You can receive daily, weekly or monthly notifications to create a chart for a collection. To do so, follow steps to edit a collection. In the **Edit Collection** sheet, turn **Show Reminders** on. Select **Daily**, **Weekly** or **Monthly**. Specify date and time. Tap **Save** to save changes.

items.title: What is the purpose of archiving a collection?
items.text: Archiving a collection closes a collection for changes. You will not be able to add new charts or modify existing charts. You might typically do that at the end of the year for example. To archive a collection, follow steps to edit a collection. In the **Edit Collection** sheet, toggle **Archive** on. Tap **Save** to save changes.

items.title: How can I view and search for entries in a collection?
items.text: Tap on **Charts** in the tab bar. Tap on the collection you want to view. Tap on header (with date of the collection). In the **Entries Overview** for the collection, tap on the buttons to sort entries on **Total points**, **Number of nr. 1 positions**, **Highest position**, **Number of chart entries** in **Ascending** or **Descending order**. Drag down to reveal the **Search** field and type any text to search for entries.

items.title: How can I define a specific period for which I want to rank entries in a collection?
items.text: In the **Edit Collection** sheet, toggle **Define Overview Period** on. Define start date and end date for the period. Tap **Save**. You can now easily toggle between a view showing entries for the specified period (**Period**) or all entries (**All**) using the calendar button on the left side of the toolbar.

items.title: How do I determine the order of charts in a collection?
items.text: Charts in a collection are ordered by chart date in descending order. You can change the order by modifying the chart date of a chart. To do this, follow steps to edit a chart. In **Edit Chart** screen, modify the **Date of Chart**. Tap **Save** to save changes.

items.title: What does locking a chart mean?
items.text: You want to lock a chart when you have completed the chart with all entries ranked, reflecting your musical taste for the chart. When locked, you are protected from making accidental changes. Also, a locked chart (and as such the chart entries) will be taken into account for calculating total points, number of chart entries, highest position, etc.. Note that you can only lock a chart when the number of entries in the chart conform to the number of entries defined for charts in the collection.

items.title: How can I delete a collection?
items.text: You can only delete a collection if it doesn't contain any charts. If so, swipe left on the specific collection in the collection list to delete the collection. Alternatively, in **Settings**, **Manage Collections**, you can delete one or more collections rapidly and definitely (so even if it contains charts and/or entries). Only do this when you are absolutely sure, as this action is irreversible.

items.title: How can I delete a chart?
items.text: Swipe left on the specific chart in the chart list to delete the chart.

items.title: How can I delete an entry?
items.text: You can only delete an individual entry if the entry is not part of any chart in the collection (i.e. there are no chart entries with a reference to the entry). To search for entries that are not part of any chart in a collection, type `FindOrphans` in the **Search** field in the **Entry Overview** screen.

items.title: What does rebuilding a collection do?
items.text: Rebuilding a collection deletes orphan entries (entries that are not part of any chart in the collection) and rebuilds the Spotlight index for a collection.

items.title: How can I update an entry?
items.text: You can update an entry by tapping on **Update** in the **Edit Entry** sheet. Note that the current artist and title of the entry will be used to search for updated music entries. Select any of the suggeated updated results to update your entry.

items.title: How can I listen to an entry?
items.text: In a chart, long press on the artwork of an entry in a chart. You will see a visual indication. To stop listening, press once more on the artwork. In the **Entry Detail** screen, tap **Play**  in the navigation bar. Tap  **Stop** to stop listening to the entry. You can also use the native music service player to stop listening to the entry. Note: The app doesn't have a in-built music player; it invokes the native music service player. As a result, buttons and visualisations might not properly reflect the status of listening to an entry. Note: For (chart) entries that do have a reference to a Spotify track / album, ensure you have a device available for Spotify to interact with. Or simply stated: have Spotify running somewhere on a device near you.

items.title: Can I add notes, subtitles?
items.text: You can add notes to a collection, chart and entry. To do so, follow the steps to edit a collection, chart or entry. When a note is added to a collection, chart or entry, you will see a pencil icon next to the title. For an entry, notes are also displayed at the bottom of the Entry Details screen. A chart also supports subtitles. Again, you can edit a subtitle by following the steps to edit a chart. The subtitle is displayed below the title in the Chart Details screen. If you use the Apple Music service integration you can quickly add Apple Music's editorial notes when available.

items.title: Can I love, like music?
items.text: If your music service supports ratings, loves or likes, you can simply love or like an entry by swiping from left to right. You first have to enable this in the settings for your collection, where you can also select to automatically love, like entries when adding to a collection.

items.title: Can I update artwork?
items.text: Artwork is automatically retrieved from the selected music service. For a blank entry, or in case you want to override the artwork, you can long tap the **Update** button when editing an entry. An alert dialog allow you to link to artwork jpg/jpeg or png.

items.title: Can I get more details about artist, album, song?
items.text: When in the details of an entry, tap the image to see all information related to the entry as available from the music service. Scroll to the bottom to retrieve more information from sources like Discocs, last.fm and Genius.

items.title: Can I disover music?
items.text: The app has Shazam functionality built-in. Use the Discover tab to discover music and rapidly add it to your collections.

items.title: Can I fast move entries in a chart?
items.text: In large charts, you can swipe an entry to the right, select the rabbit button and use the Fast Move dialog to fast move an entry to another position.

items.title: Can I import charts from a music service?
items.text: Only Apple Music supports importing charts. When using Apple Music as a music service, you can import Apple Music charts to your collection.

items.title: Hacking with Swift
items.text: Paul Hudson does a fantastic job educating simply anyone interested in Swift, SwiftUI with his [Hacking With Swift](https://www.hackingwithswift.com/) initiative. Whether its is 100 days of Swift, 100 days of SwiftUI or his Ultimate Portfolio App (which I used as an overall guidance for Chart Your Music), it is all phenomenal material brought to you in a very inspiring way with his two dogs as entertaining sidekicks.

items.title: Donny Wals
items.text: From the same country as from where I originate, Donny Wals’ [website](https://donnywals.com/) says he loves learning and sharing knowledge. His material has been instrumental in understanding the idiosyncrasies (I always wanted to use this word…) of Swift(UI) combined with Core Data and CloudKit. Also, if you want to understand Combine (still relevant despite upcoming changes announced at WWDC21) then his material is invaluable.

items.title: Big Mountain Studio
items.text: Mark Moeykens is the owner of [Big Mountain Studio](https://www.bigmountainstudio.com/) and creator of Mastery books that explain how to handle data, animations and views in SwiftUI in a very visual way and with a ton of great examples. Whether it is for reference (SwiftUI Views Mastery) or explaining concepts from start to finish (Combine Mastery in SwiftUI), his books are great educational material.

items.title: SwiftUI Weekly / Swift with Majid
items.text: Curated collection of interesting [links](https://swiftwithmajid.com/) from Majid Jabrayilov.  Together with his website Swift with Majid he shares a wealth of information on interesting topics.

items.title: SwiftLee
items.text: A weekly [blog](https://www.avanderlee.com/) about Swift, iOS, and Xcode Tips & Tricks from Antoine van der Lee, developer at WeTransfer. Again, an invaluable source of information. And b.t.w. he also developed [RocketSim](https://www.rocketsim.app/), a macOS tool to enhance the iOS simulator.

items.title: DesignCode.io
items.text: Meng To has produced [ton of materials around design and developer topics](https://designcode.io/). His specific courses on SwiftUI are excellent material, focusing specifically on user interface and user experience. Great content for inspiration.

items.title: sarunw
items.text: The [blog](https://sarunw.com) is about sharing tips and tricks, tools, and problems found along the way. What triggers me are his daily [tweets](https://twitter.com/sarunw) pointing to these tips, tricks, etc.. Everyday you learn something new!

items.title: Best-in-Class iOS App
items.text: The [Best-in-Class iOS App](https://www.bestinclassiosapp.com) is is a living, breathing document that's continually updated by Jordan Morgan.

notes.releaseNote: 2.0.0: You can now add any playlist as a chart to your collection, not only Apple Music chart playlists. For example, you can add your daily updated Apple Music Heavy Rotations Mix to a collection, or the Billboard Top 100 playlist on Spotify to a collection. When adding a playlist, you can select whether you want to add the playlist to the collection and pick entries from it later, or immediately create a new chart from the playlist. A ton of additional information is now available for your chart entries. Tap on the artwork in the entry details and you will find additional information the music service (iTunes, Apple Music, or Spotify) provides. On top of that you can retrieve information from other sources like Last.fm, Discogs, Genius. If there is more artwork available (for example liner notes, etc.) for a song or an album, it is displayed in cover flow. You can tap on any artwork to see a full screen version which you can drag and zoom for more details. The app now offers integration with Last.fm. If you have configured to like/love tracks for a collection, and you actually do like/love one or more entries, these entries are also added to your  loved tracks in Last.fm. If you play an entry through the app, the entry is added to your Last.fm scrobbles. You can configure your Last.fm account in Settings. The app also integrates with the beautiful NowPlaying app; an app to explore the hidden stories behind your favourite music & enhance your listening experience. In the Statistics screen you can now search for Artist, Entry Title amongst all entries and Chart Title amongst all charts. Added some utility admin functions, for example to delete all reminders and to make a full backup in JSON of all your collections.
2.0.1: Fixed a bug with sorting in Entry Overview
2.0.2: FIX: Solved crash when no network. FIX: Solved sorting in Entry Overview not properly working.

2.0.3: NEW: Different entries with the same id, often the results of the import of playlists, can now be merged when using Rebuild on a collection. FIX: Solved incorrect order of entries when importing Spotify playlist. FIX: Solved crash when no network. FIX: Solved sorting in Entry Overview not properly working.
2.0.4: Apologies, previous version did not include the functionality to merge duplicates. This version does...
2.0.6: Support for dark and tinted icons in iOS 18.
2.0.8: Now also supports tinted widgets.
2.0.8: FIXED: Small widget display issue resolved. FIXED: Restored large sheet size for iOS 18 on iPad instead of the new smaller default size.

2.1.0: Resolved another batch of bugs that emerged when the app was operated on iOS 18. FIXED: Rectified the problem of small widgets not displaying correctly due to oversized images. FIXED: Addressed issues with Shazam integration that led to the app freezing and crashing.
2.1.1: Some tweaks before the year ends. Look out for exciting updates in 2025! New icon for top spot in non-consecutive charts. Resolved a minor bug in English (UK) version.

2.1.2: NEW: Now you can make playlists from a collection overview, making it simple to create an end-of-year playlist on your preferred music platform. FIXED: Issue with playlist creation from long charts on Apple Music.

2.1.4: - The app is now available again for Apple Mac Silicon (designed for iPad). The previous version was marked incompatible for unknown reasons, but the App Store Connect issue has been resolved. Fingers crossed. - Fixed Share function. - Enhanced size and display of detailed artwork or artist images, especially on iPad. - Added a shortcut to the Period button in Overview. This button opens the Collection Edit screen for quick period changes.

Better error message when you try to connect to last.fm and the connection does not validate. Solved a bug with the rapid move dialog. Insert a new entry you have searched for, or an existing entry you picked from the list of existing entries, at a preferred position in the chart rather than at the last position. The preferred position is intelligently determined by the last changes you have made in a chart but can be changed before you insert the entry.
Updates to the overall UI.
Support for import and export of collections, import of editorial notes for entries, sharing charts with MusicThread.
Improved in-app on-boarding and support.
Updated to use MusicKit for Apple Music integration.
Support for large number of new iOS 15 features.
1.1.1: Bug fixes to improve the reliability and performance of the app.

1.1.2: Small updates: Using separator when showing large numbers in tiles (e.g. 10.615 instead of 10615). Entries in Pick Existing Entry sheet by now by default sorted on date rather than alphabetical. Notification in About Screen about potential updated version available in App Store.

1.1.3: For everyone: Small (bug) fixes. If you're on iOS 16: Interactive graph showing the position of an entry; just swipe across the graph in the Entry Detail view and a lollipop will provide details about date, position and points. Support for Lock Screen widget.

1.1.4: Details of a chart can now be shared directly from the chart itself using the iOS Share functionality. For Instagram specifically, you can now easily create a story or post which automatically contains the artwork of number 1 in your chart and allows you to paste additional details as text. Re-entries in a chart are now identified by using a different symbol for the previous week, rather than the same symbol for brand new entries. Fixed a bug introduced with iPadOS 16.1, where switching between two- or three panes in the UI resulted in an app crash.

1.1.5: Added sharing feature to the collection overview, so you can now share your favourite music albums, tracks, much like but way more accurate (obviously) than Spotify Wrapped or Apple Music Replay... Prevent creating duplicate entries when searching for music and selecting an entry that already exists in the collection. NOTE: This will be the last version supporting iOS 15; subsequent versions will require iOS 16.

1.1.6: This is merely an update to fully support iOS 16 (and drop support for older versions), and the newly introduced navigation unctionality introduced with it. As a result, major bugs with iPad navigation in iOS 16 should have been solved. Also fixed a number of minor bugs.

1.1.8: You can now (automatic) love / like tracks, songs, albums and it will be synced with Apple Music or Spotify, most likely resulting in better recommendations. Average position of an entry is now visible in the graph of an entry and you can view and sort on it in the overview of a collection. Introduction of push notifications. So we can occasionally inform you about anything interesting regarding the app. Widgets are enhanced to use the best text colour on top of the artwork. You can change the app icon from its default to a darker version..

1.1.9: Minor fix: Enabled smart text colour on widgets (accidentally disabled in previous version). All new features from previous version: You can now (automatic) love / like tracks, songs, albums and it will be synced with Apple Music or Spotify, most likely resulting in better recommendations. The average position of an entry is now visible in the graph of an entry and you can view and sort on it in the overview of a collection. Introduction of push notifications. So we can occasionally inform you about anything interesting regarding the app. Widgets are enhanced to use the best text colour on top of the artwork. You can change the app icon from its default to a darker version.

1.1.10: Major fix: Fixed a crash when creating a collection. Minor fix: Enabled smart text color on widgets (accidentally disabled in previous version). All new features from previous version: You can now (automatic) love / like tracks, songs, albums and it will be synced with Apple Music or Spotify, most likely resulting in better recommendations. The average position of an entry is now visible in the graph of an entry and you can view and sort on it in the overview of a collection. Introduction of push notifications. So we can occasionally inform you about anything interesting regarding the app. Widgets are enhanced to use the best text colour on top of the artwork. You can change the app icon from its default to a darker version.

1.1.11: New features: Implemented caching of artwork images to avoid artwork not showing when scrolling and on slower internet connections. Added possibility to update the artwork of an entry manually, overriding what is defined for an entry. This is especially relevant for blank entries and/or entries that can not be found in the selected music service.

1.1.12: ChartYourMusic integrates with Genius. Through this integration, you can now find a vast amount of information about your entries in a chart, ranging from song details, album details (including cover-flow experience), up until artist details. You want to know who played the violin in that one track; you can figure out directly from the app. Graphs for entries in a collection with over 25 entries are vertically condensed in size, so you can still see them in one screen on an iPhone, rather than having to scroll. From the About screen you can easily access the app's System Settings. Bug fixes...
1.1.14: Support for Shazam! You can now discover new music by letting the app listening to what is playing around you. Once discovered, you can add the music items to one or more collections.
1.1.15: Minor redesign of the Discover interface.
1.1.16: Bug fixes::Editorial notes text field behaving correctly. Automatic refresh for Entry overview.
1.1.18: Quick fix for widgets in iOS 17.
1.1.19: Fixes for application bugs introduced with iOS 17.
1.1.20: Added subtle animations in details screens. Fixed a bug in update entry sheet.

1.1.22: You can create your own Billboard Top 100, as the app now allows charts to consist of max 100 entries. You can quickly move an entry across many positions. Simply swipe an entry to the right, select the Fast Move (Rabbit) button and enter the new position. Fixed a bug with widgets.
1.1.24:  Symbols are now used in the app to distinguish between songs/tracks and albums.

1.1.26:  If you are using Apple Music as the music service in the app, you can now import Apple Music chart playlists (like the Top 100 and City Top 25) into a collection. So, aside from using the app to keep track of the music YOU love... over time..., you can now also record the musical preferences of one or more countries or cities...  Just create a collection to store a country's or city's chart playlists and start importing the chart playlist for that country or city on a daily (or regular) schedule. NOTE: This will be the last version supporting iOS 16. Newer versions of the app do require iOS 17.
